questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are false.
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are false.

options.option_text: SMTP is a mail delivery protocol.
SMTP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.
IMAP is a mail delivery protocol.
IMAP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.
question_texts: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.

options.option_text: CDN is an acronym for Content Delivery Network.
CDN is a group of servers that helps in fast delivery of web contents.
Web content is always delivered from the closest server to the client in thenetwork.

question_texts: Which of the following is correct regarding Celery?

options.option_text: Celery can be used to schedule the task.

question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding javascript language?

options.option_text: Replit.com is an example of a javascript engine.
The language supports the concept of first class functions.
The language does not allow the implementation of user defined higher orderfunctions.
The language can be used for DOM manipulation.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following method(s) does not guarantee that the displayed state and system state are kept in sync at all times?
question_texts: Which of the following method(s) does not guarantee that the displayed state and system state are kept in sync at all times?

options.option_text: Ajax requests on each UI change
Vue bindings to update data reactively
Pure static pages with all updates rendered from server

questions.question_text_1: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n).
With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n2).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n2).

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding webhooks?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding webhooks?

options.option_text: A webhook uses web socket protocol.
A webhook receiver must be deployed on the same origin as the webhookinitiator.
A webhook is supposed to be used for machine to machine communication

question_texts: Which of the following is correct regarding XSS attacks?

options.option_text: XSS attack is an exploit where an attacker attaches a malicious code into awebsite.
XSS can be used to steal the user's cookie.
XSS is a client side injection attack.
It can be avoided by validating the user's input.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding long and short polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding long and short polling?

options.option_text: A webhook is the same as short polling.
The short polling can be used to know the state of an asynchronous task, andtrigger an action if the task gets completed.
The long polling cannot be achieved using HTTP protocol.
Long Polling can be used to achieve real time communication

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding caching?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding caching?

options.option_text: It is recommended to cache the social networking apps feed responses for alonger duration.
Caching is primarily done to reduce the load from the origin server.
The shared cache is meant to serve responses to the multiple users.
A browser cannot cache JavaScript corresponding to a web page.

options.option_text: CORS stands for Cross Origin Resource Sharing.
The CORS reduces chances of malicious code by explicitly saying which URLscan be originators of data.
CSRF stands for Cross Site Request Forgery.

options.option_text: A celery system may consist of multiple brokers.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Modern Application Development II"** exam, along with **key equations** (where applicable) and **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. Web Protocols & Communication** #### **1. Email Protocols** - **SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)** - Used for **sending emails** (mail delivery). - **Ports**: 25 (unencrypted), 587 (TLS), 465 (SSL). - **Not used for retrieving emails** (false statement in exam). - **IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)** - Used for **retrieving emails** from a server. - Supports **synchronization** (e.g., marking emails as read). - **POP3 (Post Office Protocol)** - Also for retrieving emails but **downloads and deletes** from the server by default. #### **2. HTTP/HTTPS & WebSockets** - **HTTP/HTTPS**: Stateless protocol for client-server communication. - **WebSockets**: Full-duplex, persistent connection for **real-time communication** (e.g., chat apps). - **Webhooks**: - **Machine-to-machine communication** via HTTP callbacks. - **Not WebSocket-based** (false statement in exam). - **No same-origin policy restriction** (can be cross-origin). #### **3. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)** - **Same-Origin Policy (SOP)**: Restricts requests to the same **protocol + domain + port**. - **CORS Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: Specifies allowed origins. - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: Allowed HTTP methods (GET, POST, etc.). - **When CORS Errors Occur**: - Different **domain** (`abc.com` vs. `def.com`). - Different **protocol** (`http` vs. `https`). - Different **port** (`:80` vs. `:8080`). - Different **subdomain** (`abc.com` vs. `sub.abc.com`). #### **4. CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)** - **Attack**: Tricks users into submitting malicious requests. - **Mitigation**: - **CSRF Tokens**: Unique tokens per session. - **SameSite Cookies**: Restrict cookie sending to same-site requests. --- #### **5. CDN (Content Delivery Network)** - **Purpose**: Reduce latency by caching content on **edge servers** closer to users. - **How it Works**: - User requests content → CDN serves from the **nearest edge server**. - **Does not guarantee** the closest server is always used (depends on routing). - **Use Cases**: Static assets (images, JS, CSS), videos, APIs. --- ### **B. Asynchronous JavaScript & Real-Time Systems** #### **1. Polling vs. Webhooks vs. WebSockets** | Method | Description | Pros | Cons | |-----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|-------------------------------| | **Short Polling** | Client repeatedly asks the server for updates. | Simple to implement. | High latency, server load. | | **Long Polling** | Client holds a request open until the server responds or times out. | Lower latency than short. | Complex, connection drops. | | **Webhooks** | Server pushes data to a client URL when an event occurs. | Real-time, efficient. | Needs a public endpoint. | | **WebSockets** | Persistent full-duplex connection between client and server. | Lowest latency, bidirectional.| Complex setup, stateful. | - **Long Polling ≠ Webhooks** (false statement in exam). - **Webhooks use HTTP**, not WebSockets. #### **2. Celery (Distributed Task Queue)** - **Components**: - **Broker** (Redis, RabbitMQ): Stores tasks. - **Workers**: Execute tasks. - **Result Backend** (optional): Stores task results. - **Features**: - **Task Scheduling**: Run tasks at specific times. - **Retries**: Automatic retries on failure. - **Multiple Brokers**: Can use Redis, RabbitMQ, etc. (not limited to Redis). - **Scaling**: - **Point-to-point**: O(n²) connections (each worker connects to every other). - **Broker-based**: O(n) connections (all workers connect to a central broker). #### **3. Promises & Async/Await** - **Promise States**: - **Pending** → **Fulfilled** (resolved) or **Rejected**. - **Async/Await**: - `await` pauses execution until the promise settles. - **Error Handling**: Use `try/catch`. - **Example**: ```javascript async function fetchData() { try { const data = await fetch(url); return data.json(); } catch (err) { console.error("Network Error"); } } ``` #### **4. Event Loop & `setTimeout`** - **JavaScript is single-threaded** but uses an **event loop** for async operations. - **`setTimeout` with `var` in loops**: ```javascript for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) { setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1000); // Logs 3, 3, 3 (closure issue) } ``` - **Fix**: Use `let` or an IIFE. --- ### **C. Frontend Frameworks (Vue.js)** #### **1. Vue Directives** - **`v-for`**: Loop over arrays/objects. ```vue
``` - **`v-model`**: Two-way data binding (e.g., ``). - **`v-bind`**: Dynamically bind attributes (`:class`, `:style`). #### **2. Vue Reactivity** - **Reactive Data**: Changes in `data()` trigger UI updates. - **Computed Properties**: Cached derived data. ```javascript computed: { total() { return this.items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0); } } ``` - **Watchers**: React to data changes. ```javascript watch: { question(newVal) { this.fetchAnswer(newVal); } } ``` #### **3. Vue Router** - **Dynamic Routes**: ```javascript { path: '/user/:id', component: User, props: true } ``` - `props: true` passes route params as props. - **Wildcard (`*`)**: Catch-all for 404 pages. #### **4. Slots (Component Composition)** - **Default Slot**: `` - **Named Slots**: `` - **Usage**: ```vue ``` #### **5. Vuex (State Management)** - **Core Concepts**: - **State**: Single source of truth. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state changes. - **Actions**: Async operations (commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed state (like computed properties). - **Example**: ```javascript mutations: { updateStudents(state) { state.below_average = state.students.filter(s => s.marks > 50); } } ``` --- ### **D. Security** #### **1. XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)** - **Types**: - **Stored XSS**: Malicious script saved on the server (e.g., in a DB). - **Reflected XSS**: Script embedded in a URL. - **DOM-based XSS**: Script executes in the browser via DOM manipulation. - **Mitigation**: - **Input Sanitization**: Strip `
